items.abstract: This chapter presents a commentary on distinguishing but not dissociating psychiatric disorder and impairment in functioning. It explores Hume’s ideas about moral goodness and badness, the basis of sentiment in moral evaluations, the usefulness of distinguishing between psychiatric disorder and functional impairment, and how this relates to cultural norms.
title: Distinguishing but not dissociating psychiatric disorder and impairment in functioning: Bolton, Hume, and sentiment
original-title: Distinguishing but not dissociating psychiatric disorder and impairment in functioning: Bolton, Hume, and sentiment

items.abstract: This chapter explores the concept of scientific progress by contrasting a gradual epistemic iteration approach to the classification of personality disorder with a revolutionary paradigm-shifting approach. Commitment to one or the other approach partly fueled disagreements about whether to adopt a dimensional model for personality disorder in DSM-5. One of the Scientific Review Committee’s concerns was that over-reliance on the preferences of small groups of experts will not support cumulative progress, rather; the trajectory will either resemble a random walk or it will “wobble” based on shifting conceptual preferences.Work group members who wanted to transition to a more dimensional model believed that the DSM-IV model was a classificatory dead end, and a gradual iteration strategy could not support progress. For both groups progress was construed as an increasingly accurate approximation of psychiatric reality. The chapter offers an alternative account of scientific progress based on coherentist and pragmatist perspectives.
title: Epistemic iteration or paradigm shift: The case of personality disorder
original-title: Epistemic iteration or paradigm shift: The case of personality disorder
